review_title: Day to day experience is luck of the draw, but lots of caring people
pros:
-Investment in ongoing training at the organizational level. You may have to invest quite a bit of personal time to take advantage of it, to be fair. but it's available.
-Multiple genuine leaders who care about helping people develop their careers. Business outcomes will always come first, but people generally try to help you achieve some of your goals too.
-90% of people are open to coffee chats with just a slack msg or an email. And there are tons of people worth coffee chatting. 
-New hires get 3 weeks PTO immediately, I don't think that's the case everywhere
-Good pay in my opinion. If you just want to be able to live comfortably, and save comfortably it's a good salary.
cons:
-As with consulting in a lot of places, a lot depends on your project & project team. I personally had poor WLB on a few successive projects, however others hired at the same time as me fared better. Luck of the draw. 
-Some people may be drawn to the company due to the variety of work it does, with the hopes of being able to try different things over the course of their IBM career. This is easier said than done. Transitions from the group that originally hired you can be very tricky and political. Mastery is also quite highly valued as it helps sell work to clients, so having people start almost from scratch in new subject areas can be unattractive to leadership
-To my knowledge, people become managers on a volunteer basis. Not sure there's much additional incentive for them other than it looking good for future advancement. This inevitably leads to some people who don't have the skills for people mgmt / coaching (though they may be highly skilled at project delivery, etc) in that role. Networking within the company may be your only hope for advancing your career goals if you end up with a manager that shouldn't be a manager. The good thing is 90% of people are pretty open to networking .

job_title: Program Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: - Super smart and nice people
cons:
- IBM claims to provide many resources, including educational reimbursement. When I enrolled in a graduate program directly related to my job role, I was denied that benefit despite being deemed as a high potential employee. 
- Of 19 leaders posted on the corporate web site, only 5 are women and 3 POC. It makes IBM's claims about supporting DEI meaningless. 
- In my 4.5 years, I've seen annual changes in strategy that have resulted in zero changes in execution. 
- In my time at Big Blue, 100% of leaders recruited from outside or brought in through acquisition have left after 1-5 years.
- While there have been recent marginal improvements, processes and compliance taxes are EXTREMELY onerous and opaque. 
- Navigating the vast number of employees, the constant organizational changes, and the embedded/phlegmetic/lethargic sense of entitlement is exhausting and counter-productive.

pros:
Below are the pros I have observed so far being a DevOps Engineer in IBM.
1. Supportive leadership
2. Lots of content for learning
3. Good exposure to various technologies.
4. Good benefits from Employer including health insurance, dental insurance, bonus, stocks, Pension plans etc.
cons: I haven't seen much cons as of now being part of this organization. One thing I observed is that we generally see plenty of engagements to keep ourselves busy and implement our knowledge. Some of the time(1-2 months), we don't see any engagement (You can either utilize this period for improving your skills or waste this time doing nothing)

pros: Amazing work environment to work.

job_title: People Manager in Caloocan, Quezon City
pros: Work From Home is available depending on type of work. High on diversity. Free online learning course. You will learn to stay relevant and competitive in a fast paced environment.
cons: Expect very seldom career growth opportunity. Be ready to accept more work and responsibility. Extended or long hours of work is a norm. You will experience many critical work days/periods in which you will not be able to take vacation leave. Best of luck if they happen to fall on an important family occasion. Senior management are usually too busy they can't schedule a decent or quality time for one on one meeting. If they do manage to schedule one, good luck on feeling the sincerity because more often it becomes robotic or routinely for compliance. Out of 10 managers I have experienced on my entire career only 2 managers which was during my early years were able to show sincerity and genuine concern about me as an employee and my career development. Over the years, I have seen how the work culture declined. What was once a happy, sharing of best practices and helping each other type of work environment became a highly competitive one. People became focused on job security because of the rampant and aggressive company or business operation changes. My advise is to check back after 2-3 years when they are probably more stable.

job_title: Senior User Experience Researcher in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
The best part of IBM are the people - they are relationships you can carry throughout your life. I have made many lifelong connections at IBM.
IBM also does an amazing job on educating their current workers. I learned about Tools (most recently SurveyGizmo, Mural, and Slack), but also about myself -- like my Collaboration and Leadership styles -- through classes about Teamwork, Negotiation, Inclusiveness, Personal Bias, Open Mindset and Emotional Intelligence. 
All of these helped me realize what type of person I wanted to be and led to improvements in both my personal and professional relationships.
Basically IBM helped me to learn and develop myself into a better and happier person. I am proud to be an IBMer.
cons:
IBM is made up of smaller organizations, which can feel like mini-companies themselves. Since each group manages themselves, the experience can be quite different between and across groups/teams. A few groups I worked with, were more interested in the bottom lines or numbers, rather than the team or individuals on projects. These were few for me, although I did gain some useful knowledge on how to deal with aggression while keeping a positive spin on rebuttals and counter proposals.
Also IBM does not always pay top dollar to their employees, which can be frustrating. Current world events makes this difficult to change or impact.

pros:
-IBM has above average benefits. They match dollar-for-dollar in our 401(k) plans; they have a variety of health plan options; they also have an advocate hotline for employees to deal with insurance questions/claims.

-IBM has a vast social network. Whether you have pto questions, project specific questions, or just need another set of eyes to review a solution, there are colleagues willing to help. 

-IBM emphasizes continuing education. There are vast resources (databases, search engines, courses, industry knowledge) available to supplement projects.

-IBM covers the cost of job-specific trainings through vouchers.

-The people are great to work with on projects. They come from vast and diverse backgrounds.
cons:
-Some leadership fixate on short-term vs long-term wins (positioning inexperienced college grads as SME's, not pushing back on clients for fear it could sever future work)

-I'm so focused on project delivery that I don't know how my function adds value my clients. I don't know how my work adds value to IBM.

-There's lack of information on how to move laterally or upwards in my career. I've stopped asking my boss and others because it doesn't lead to anything insightful.

pros: The fact that IBM is immersed into almost every industry and governments throughout the world affords many opportunities to work in a broad spectrum of roles and jobs. It is refreshing to see the level of effort that IBM'ers put into helping each other here.

review_title: IBM India is a good place to work if you are consistent.
pros:
Overall healthy environment. Focus on your work, keep publishing articles, papers, assets... keep yourself visible. So many opportunities to learn and grow.

"Great place to work for women" (in quotes...). Policies and culture are very sensitive towards women's safety.
cons:
Few points:
* Very easy to get in the comfort zone. There are fix formulas to survive in IBM, and they keep changing with time. Complete projects with 'n' rating, publish 'n' articles/assets/papers and you are good till next KRA. On the face, this looks fair, but this is manipulated with 'visibility'. Visibility in IBM is like SEO (search engine optimization). And there are non-organic ways to increase your visibility. I'm not suggesting that this is the fault of IBM, this is just humans being human (or desis). 

* Growth is slow in general unless you have great visibility. 

* Organization has no face. You can work in IBM for years and years and never meet your manager, or somebody from accounts, HR, etc. . Everything happens via systems, which work like a well-oiled machine. But without faces it gets uninspiring. Nobody is there to push you to grow, to learn further, to actually innovate. So if you are not self-driven... you find yourself either in your comfort zone or in survival mode.

So find a mentor and few close friends near your cubicle (or in your Zoom call list), regardless of their role, competency, or color (of the project... Green/Yellow/Red, etc. )

job_title: Applications Developer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros:
As a current IBM employee, it depresses me sometimes to think back on my past employers and just how many of those workplaces were managed by "man/woman-children" who -- more often than not -- let emotion and personal biases control the daily decisions they make. At those places, *genuinely* good ideas by lower-level staff would be ignored 100% of the time if the idea somehow threatens the manager’s brittle ego or even *slightly* increases their workload. These were Tywin Lannister-wannabes I’m talking about – that view their employees as a group of undisciplined children requiring constant supervision, restricting the tiniest of freedoms and establishing authority by reprimanding non-offenses. For these "control-gestapos", managing isn't the goal. Coasting through a life of upper-middle class perks and authority (in title only) is their only motivation. They inhibit any and all culture and creativity from a work environment and drain the lifeforce out of their staff. Sirius Black would never have escaped if Azkaban had a swarm of micromanagers flying around in black hoods. I will be honest with you here… I consider each and every single one of these Putin-sympathizing, workplace-tyrants out there actively defiling our country’s workplaces to be my eternal arch-rivals. 

I guess what I’m trying to say here is IBM does a good job of saying “do this thing by the end of the month” and leaving you alone.
cons: You will be constantly losing roles to other IBM-employees who are more qualified because their CV shows they previously worked in a similar role.

pros: The merger itself wasn't bad. Nobody knew anything about how long IBM was going to keep us, but they held a nice convention, gave us all laptops, and told us what we needed to know to get started.

review_title: Hopefully doing a big turnaround... heading in the right direction!
job_title: User Experience Designer in Hursley, England
pros:
Recent leadership changes (last year) are really prioritising growth.
Very accomodating and flexible place to work.
Amazingly passionate technical teams who LOVE the technologies they work with.
cons:
1. Bureaucracy, bureaucracy, bureaucracy! Totallly siloed business restricts the innovation that teams can actually perform. Business processes are so opaque and varied across business units and even manager to manager.
2. Slow to act on climate goals - employees branded "idealists" for asking climate-related questions in CEO ask-me-anythings.
3. Had to essentially get another job offer on the table to get an overdue promotion. Requests were ignored despite having ~8 senior employee support statements. Ended up happening in the middle of a bad quarter, which gave leadership the appearance of being shocked and desperate. 
4. So many people! IBM has one of the biggest workforces in the world - and isn't moving fast as a result. Definitely adopted Agile (in some teams) but not Lean!
5. Often hard to trace through from corporate strategy to your functional role... but this is getting better with concerted effort from leadership sharing strategy.
6. Very few opportunities for progression in the UK in comparison to the rest of the world - and no opportunity to relocate.

job_title: Product Management in New York, NY
pros:
- At IBM you will be working on big, complex problems, for some of the world's largest and most impactful clients & brands - it's easy to feel like you're making an impact
- Tons of career flexibility - I started with IBM in sales, have done partnership development, corporate strategy, and Product Management since then. If you want to grow or pivot your career without going back to school - there's a lot of opportunity for you. 
- Great, smart people to work with
- If you are willing to take the initiative and are organized, there is tremendous career opportunity for you to move up and land promotions. There isn't a cookie cutter, checklist approach to promotions, but that ambiguity represents great opportunity for many.
cons:
- Work life balance is pretty bad. Part of this is baked in given how international IBM is - so many teams are spread across the globe. Part of this is cultural and while improving, is still an issue
- Your happiness at IBM is highly dependent on your direct management and skip. If you have a bad, Program Director, Director or VP in your reporting chain, your life will be materially worse at IBM than otherwise, and unfortunately this happens quite a bit.
- an addition to the above - promotions are sometimes merit-based, sometimes who kisses up and kicks down most effectively. This is pretty common at large organizations, and IBM is quite a large organization. Again, as an employee joining, this will affect your fulfillment at IBM. 

If you're interviewing - I'd highly recommend about asking about the culture *on the team you're joining* specifically, as well as asking about the people you'd be reporting to in the role.
